Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Large Scale Structure with 21cm Intensity Mapping
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative program will conduct a multi-year project to make precise measurements of the large scale structure of the universe using recently developed 21 cm intensity mapping techniques. The program will create spectral maps of 500 square degrees, spanning the frequency range 700 to 900 MHz (0.58 < z < 1). The principal goal is to measure the baryon acoustic oscillation feature at these redshifts in an innovative program which is complementary to, and competitive with, optical galaxy surveys. The acoustic scale provides a standard ruler which measures the Universe's expansion, providing an observational handle on Dark Energy.

Broader impacts of the work include training of graduate student, and outreach to the public via a planetarium show called "The Hydrogen Sky" produced in English, French and Chinese, and distributed worldwide. Additional outreach activities include tours of the night sky through the Universe in the Park program in Wisconsin and teaching electronics to under-represented groups through CMU's Summer Academy for Math and Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used the Green Bank Telescope to measure, for the first time, the weblike structure of the Universe, using the 21-cm radio emission of hydrogen gas. We were able to measure the amount of 21-cm structure despite much stronger emission from electrons spiraling in the magentic field of the Milky Way. This demonstration has led to the construction of several new large telescopes around the world. Ultimately, we plan to use 21-cm maps made with these telescopes to study the mysterious dark matter and dark energy that account for 96 percent of the matter and energy in the universe today.

We also detected a mysterious "fast radio burst" in our data.  These are flashes that appear on the radio sky, sweeping across wavelength for a few seconds, then disappear, never to repeat.  They may be evidence of the explosions of distant stars, or of impacts of comets on neutron stars in distant galaxies. However we understand very little about these burst beacuse so far no counterparts have been detected with optical telescopes. Previously, these burst were thought to come from sources here on earth, but the charateristics of the burst we detected have all the hallmarks of a source halfway across the universe. The new 21-cm telescopes now under construction will also be very prolofic sensors for these burst, catching up to ten per day, and pinpointing their location, allowing optical counterparts to be identified.

We created a draft video, formated for planetarium domes, that explains our work.
